content.description: Up through great patina flakes on a very cool wall.
content.protection: 8 bolts to gate-less cold-shuts anchor without hangers. Route starts on boulder atop 10-15' crevice making clipping first bolt possibly PG-13.

content.location: to the left of tech-9, right of full auto

content.description: Crux involves getting situated on the wall after stepping out from starting boulder. Thin face moves with good lieback positions at the beginning transition into an easier middle section. Shake out the pump as the final section is pumpy with unique hands and less than optimal feet. Three stars

Climb the corner/buttress left of the bolts using face holds and a crack in the corner, stemming between the wall and the buttress. Relatively easy climbing through the bolts.

Clip the third bolt and make some balancey moves on small, tenuous holds (crux) to establish yourself in the crack--which is thin (fingers) at first, but widens quickly to hands.

Easier climbing in the somewhat flaring hand crack about 15-20 feet until a small bulge/roof (2nd crux). Hands thin out again at/above the roof for some awkward/tricky moves with decent feet.

Anchor is 10 feet above the roof.
content.protection: Three bolts to start, then large nuts and a small selection of cams from fingers to C4 #3 should do it. Most people will want tape, too. Open shuts anchor.
content.location:
This route is far left on the Patina Wall--up the gully about 50 ft. from Tec-9.  I do not believe it is in the San Diego County guidebook. It is on a hand-drawn topo of the wall (by Chris Hubbard

climbingtoposofsandiego.com

), farthest route out left.

It starts in a right-facing corner just to the right of a pillar with some cool-looking hueco features at the base (see BETA photo). Look for three bolts that end at an undulating hand crack.

content.description: Crux is between 3rd and 4th bolt. First 25 feet are a blast, but once your done with the crux its about a 5.8+
content.location: On the patina wall. one route in between this and tech-9 (street sweeper)

content.description: The first route to be put up on the Patina Wall.  Just right of Tec-9.  The top is entertaining with finger-lockoffs in small cracks.  Goes through mostly dark brown patina towards the top.

Hard crux start leads to solid jugs above on a steep, exposed wall. Itâ€™s a playground of patina. Really fun route. It shares the start as the other 11c (called M 11) to the left. See Climbing Topos of San Diego for more info.
content.location: Down to the right of Tec-9, a few boulders down the gulley.

content.description: Towards the very left of the wall. This is a fun short climb that is pretty pumpy. Crux is towards the very top. One star in the book, but it deserves more than that.

Climb follows a short flake onto some delicate face moves to a neat top-out. Fairly chossy, be mindful of your feet slipping on the loose gravel. Protection ends after the flake, so the next 15 feet to the top are mellow but dangerous. A fall from the top would mean hitting the ground. No bolts, walk off the back. Could be a boulder problem, but not for those faint of heart.
content.protection: Placed 2 cams, could probably get away with just one
content.location: The boulder is at the base of the Patina Wall, facing the road. The flake can be seen from the road. If you approach along the right side of the Patina Wall gully, you will walk right by it.
